evidence.pdf_reference: conditions.The third was illuminated using visible light in the presence of the catalyst, while flowing N 2 rather than CO 2 .No product was detected in all of the above three blank tests.This showed that the reaction demanded catalyst and illumination, and that the products were obtained by the photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide in NaOH solution.

and TiO 2 (BH-1) for the photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide in NaOH aqueous medium at ambient conditions under 10 h of irradiation.TiO 2 particles (this work) with CoPc show a higher photocatalytic activity than undoped TiO 2 and TiO 2 (BH-1), and the optimal CoPc loading was found to be 0.5 wt.The products of the photoreduction of CO 2 in NaOH solution exhibited a dependence on the catalyst.The formation of formic acid was found to be much more pronounced on supported CoPc-TiO 2 catalysts.At the

scheme for the photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide in NaOH solution is proposed as follows.Photoexcited electrons (e -) and positive holes (h -) are produced when incident photons are absorbed in CoPc-TiO 2 , and then transfer to TiO 2 and CoPc respectively (eqn (4)).Therefore, the photoexcited electrons and holes in the lattices are separated and trapped by appropriate sites of CoPc-TiO 2 to avoid recombination.CO 2 molecules adsorbed on the surface of TiO 2 gain electrons and are reduced to CO, CH

Catalysts were prepared at room temperature using a sol-gel method, as illustrated in Fig. 1.The precursor was titanium(IV) butoxide (Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 , 97).Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 was dissolved in anhydrous ethanol, and then mixed with acetic acid and a little hydrochloric acid under stirring.To avoid precipitation during polycondensation and the formation of unstable colloidal sols, the hydrolyzing water was homogeneously released by the esterification of ethanol and acetic acid. 13CoPc was added into Fig. 1 The
